content.title: Recession
content.definition: A recession is a significant decline in economic activity spread across the economy, lasting more than a few months, normally visible in real GDP, real income, employment, industrial production, and wholesale-retail sales. The NBER Business Cycle Dating Committee officially dates US recessions based on comprehensive analysis rather than a rigid formula. The popular 'two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth' is a rough approximation, not the official definition. Recessions represent the contraction phase of the business cycle, typically characterized by rising unemployment, falling output, declining investment, and reduced consumer spending.

definitions_glossary.recession: Significant decline in economic activity spread across economy, lasting more than a few months (NBER definition)
definitions_glossary.depression: Severe and prolonged recession - no formal definition, but typically GDP decline >10% or lasting >3 years (e.g., 1930s)
definitions_glossary.technical_recession: Two consecutive quarters of negative real GDP growth - common shorthand but not official NBER definition
definitions_glossary.output_gap: Y - Y* = Actual GDP minus potential GDP - negative during recessions (economy below capacity)
definitions_glossary.cyclical_unemployment: Unemployment above natural rate due to recession - the component policy aims to eliminate
definitions_glossary.automatic_stabilizers: Tax and spending programs that automatically expand during recession (unemployment benefits, reduced tax collection)
definitions_glossary.fiscal_stimulus: Discretionary government spending increase or tax cut to boost aggregate demand during recession
definitions_glossary.monetary_easing: Central bank rate cuts or QE to stimulate borrowing and spending during recession
definitions_glossary.trough: Bottom of recession - point where decline stops and recovery begins (dated by NBER)
definitions_glossary.recovery: Expansion phase following trough - economy growing back toward previous peak
definitions_glossary.jobless_recovery: Expansion where output grows but employment remains depressed (2001, 2009 recoveries)
definitions_glossary.balance_sheet_recession: Recession caused by private sector deleveraging (paying down debt rather than spending)
definitions_glossary.v_shaped_recovery: Sharp decline followed by equally rapid recovery (COVID 2020)

key_points: NBER definition: 'Significant decline in economic activity spread across economy, lasting more than a few months'
Not just 'two negative quarters' - NBER examines employment, income, production, sales comprehensively
US recessions since 1945: Average duration 11 months, average GDP decline ~2%
Great Recession (2007-09): 18 months, 4.3% GDP decline - most severe since 1930s
COVID recession (2020): Only 2 months but 10% GDP decline in Q2 - deepest quarterly drop ever
Causes: Demand shocks (confidence collapse, financial crisis), supply shocks (oil, pandemic), policy errors
Key symptoms: Rising unemployment, falling industrial production, declining retail sales, falling investment
Policy response: Automatic stabilizers + discretionary fiscal/monetary stimulus to restore aggregate demand
Recession impacts: Permanent output loss (scarring), long-term unemployment, reduced human capital accumulation
Recession prediction: Yield curve inversion, consumer confidence, leading indicators - but timing uncertain

examples.title: Great Recession (December 2007 - June 2009)
examples.description: Triggered by housing bubble burst and financial crisis (Lehman Brothers collapse September 2008). Duration: 18 months - longest since Great Depression. GDP fell 4.3%, unemployment rose from 5% to 10%. Causes: Subprime mortgage crisis → bank failures → credit freeze → collapse of aggregate demand. Response: TARP bailouts, Fed zero rates and QE, ARRA fiscal stimulus. Recovery: Slow 'jobless recovery' - unemployment stayed high until 2015.
examples.context: Most severe post-war US recession - financial crisis driven
examples.data: Peak: Dec 2007. Trough: June 2009. Duration: 18 months. GDP: -4.3%. Unemployment: 5% → 10% (peaked Oct 2009)

examples.title: COVID-19 Recession (February 2020 - April 2020)
examples.description: Shortest recession in US history: Only 2 months. But deepest quarterly decline: GDP fell 31% annualized in Q2 2020. Cause: Pandemic lockdowns and fear - exogenous shock, not typical demand/financial trigger. Unemployment spiked from 3.5% to 14.7% in one month. Response: Massive fiscal ($5T+) and monetary (Fed QE, zero rates) support. Recovery: Rapid V-shaped bounce due to reopening and stimulus.
examples.data: Peak: Feb 2020. Trough: Apr 2020. Duration: 2 months. Q2 GDP: -31% annualized. Unemployment: 3.5% → 14.7%

examples.title: Early 1980s Double-Dip Recession
examples.description: Two recessions in quick succession: Jan-July 1980 (6 months) and July 1981-Nov 1982 (16 months). Caused by Volcker Fed's aggressive rate hikes to 20% to break 13% inflation. Deliberate policy-induced recession to restore price stability. Unemployment reached 10.8% (highest since Depression). Result: Inflation broken, fell to 3% by 1983. Painful but necessary 'sacrifice ratio' demonstrated.
examples.context: Deliberate policy-induced recession to fight inflation
examples.data: Fed funds rate: 20% (1980-81). Inflation: 13% → 3%. Unemployment: 10.8% peak (Nov 1982). Total contraction: 22 months

examples.title: 2001 Dot-Com Recession
examples.description: March 2001 - November 2001 (8 months). Triggered by technology stock bubble burst (NASDAQ fell 78%), 9/11 attacks. Mild recession: GDP barely negative, unemployment rose from 4% to 6%. Notable for 'jobless recovery' afterward - GDP grew but employment stagnated. Fed cut rates aggressively (6.5% → 1%). Some argue easy money contributed to subsequent housing bubble.
examples.context: Tech bubble burst and terrorism shock
examples.data: Duration: 8 months. NASDAQ: -78% from peak. Unemployment: 4% → 6%. Fed funds: 6.5% → 1%

examples.title: Japan's Lost Decade(s) - Prolonged Stagnation
examples.description: Not one recession but prolonged stagnation after 1991 bubble burst. GDP growth averaged only 1%/year for 20 years. Deflation persisted despite near-zero interest rates (liquidity trap). Balance sheet recession: Banks and firms deleveraged, reducing spending. Multiple policy failures: Premature fiscal tightening, delayed monetary response. Demonstrates: Some recessions have lasting structural effects - 'L-shaped' rather than V-shaped recovery.
examples.data: Japan GDP growth: 1%/year (1991-2010) vs 4%+ (1980s). Deflation from late 1990s. Lost Decade(s) lasting 20+ years

content.statement: A recession represents a significant, broad-based decline in economic activity that causes substantial hardship through rising unemployment, falling incomes, and reduced economic opportunity. Understanding recession causes, characteristics, policy responses, and long-term effects is essential for macroeconomic analysis and policymaking.

explanation.intuition: A recession is like the economy catching a cold - or sometimes the flu. Economic activity slows down: businesses sell less, so they produce less, so they employ fewer workers, who then have less income to spend, causing businesses to sell even less. This negative feedback loop is why recessions can be self-reinforcing. The severity depends on what caused the recession (financial crisis = more severe), how quickly policy responds (faster = shorter recession), and structural factors (debt levels, labor market flexibility). Recovery happens when something breaks the cycle: policy stimulus boosts demand, confidence returns, or pent-up spending is finally released.
explanation.key_insight: The crucial insight is that recessions are not just inevitable dips but periods that can cause permanent damage (hysteresis/scarring). Long-term unemployment erodes skills and reduces future employability. Firms that fail don't come back. Workers who lose jobs in recessions have lower lifetime earnings. Investment foregone means less future productive capacity. This is why policy intervention matters: shorter, shallower recessions minimize permanent damage. The debate is how much intervention is appropriate (risk of over-intervention: inflation, debt), not whether to respond at all. The Great Recession taught that insufficient response prolongs suffering; COVID taught that aggressive response enables rapid recovery.
explanation.technical_details: NBER Dating Committee examines: (1) Real personal income less transfers, (2) Nonfarm payroll employment, (3) Real personal consumption expenditures, (4) Wholesale-retail sales, (5) Industrial production, (6) Household survey employment. Recession declared when majority show significant decline for several months. Peak dated when activity reaches highest point, trough when it reaches lowest. Output gap = (Y - Y*)/Y* where Y* is potential GDP. Okun's Law: 1pp unemployment above natural rate ≈ 2% negative output gap. Automatic stabilizers: Tax revenue falls (less income to tax) + transfer spending rises (unemployment benefits) ≈ ~1-2% GDP fiscal impulse automatically. Discretionary fiscal multiplier: 0.5-2.0 depending on economic conditions (higher at ZLB).

mathematical_formulation.output_gap: (Y - Y*)/Y* where Y* is potential GDP (negative in recession)
mathematical_formulation.recession_probability: Probit: P(recession) = Φ(α + β × yield_spread + γ × other_indicators)

demand_shock_recession.cause: Fall in consumer/business confidence, investment collapse, financial crisis
demand_shock_recession.mechanism: AD shifts left → output falls, prices fall (or rise slower)
demand_shock_recession.policy: Fiscal and monetary stimulus to restore AD

supply_shock_recession.cause: Oil price spike, pandemic, natural disaster affecting production
supply_shock_recession.mechanism: AS shifts left → output falls, prices rise (stagflation)
supply_shock_recession.policy: Dilemma - can't simultaneously fight inflation and recession

policy_induced_recession.cause: Central bank raises rates to fight inflation
policy_induced_recession.mechanism: Higher rates → lower I and C → AD falls → recession
policy_induced_recession.purpose: Break inflation expectations, restore price stability

balance_sheet_recession.cause: Excessive private debt leads to deleveraging
balance_sheet_recession.mechanism: Firms/households pay down debt instead of spending
balance_sheet_recession.challenge: Monetary policy less effective - borrowers don't want loans

recession_costs.output_loss: GDP below potential - direct welfare cost
recession_costs.scarring: Long-term damage: reduced future earnings, lower productivity
recession_costs.investment: Foregone capital accumulation reduces future capacity
recession_costs.social: Increased poverty, health problems, social instability
recession_costs.political: Incumbents lose elections, extremism may rise

concepts: Electoral consequences: Incumbents punished for recessions
Political instability: Recessions can fuel extremism
Mental health: Unemployment linked to depression, anxiety
Behavioral responses: Precautionary saving in uncertainty

verified_claims.claim: Post-WWII US recessions average 11 months duration
verified_claims.derivation: NBER data: Average contraction duration 11.1 months (1945-2020). 12 recessions in this period ✓

verified_claims.claim: Great Recession was 18 months and GDP fell 4.3%
verified_claims.derivation: NBER: Peak Dec 2007, Trough June 2009 = 18 months. BEA: Real GDP decline 4.3% peak-to-trough ✓

verified_claims.claim: COVID recession was only 2 months duration
verified_claims.derivation: NBER: Peak Feb 2020, Trough Apr 2020 = 2 months. Shortest recession in US history ✓
